Early Access Review
								This is one of these where you feel sad to not recommend it. Let me start by stating that I believe the developers can and probably will fix any issues that crop up in the game - I can see the effort they put into it, and hopefully I can explain why I don't recommend it at the moment.This is not a simple YES / NO review. So I advise you to read further before downvoting or thinking the game is bad.For an Early Access title, it's a very well polished product. The graphics are good, the interface is nice, and the audio is great, and there's few bugs.However, even though the game is well made and has good potential if further developed, its current core gameplay is repetitive and not really fun. Which is exactly why I can't recommend it: it's not a matter of specific, isolated issues. The CORE of the game feels pointless at this time.COMBAT: Battles are EXTREMELY slow, repetitive, unsatisfying and not rewarding as one might think. I'm sad to say it's the worst pacing and balancing I've experienced from this sort of FTL-insipired games. It feels like Sid Meyer's Pirates in space (which is good and could be a lot of fun) with a slight touch of FTL.Even after I got the most expensive combat ship, and decent skill on battles, it still felt wrong, and kind of boring. Enemies may surrender and offer you a good amount for their lives, however, which is a great thing to see when it works - very few games I played have such feature.TRADING: The game doesn't provide enough info to make sense of the economy. And even though it follows a basic supply/demand and consumption/production cycle, there's no influence in the game universe beyond that. Trading is a simple mindless grind, which wouldn't be that big of a deal if it could be automated. And once you figure out a good run, you can have everyhing in the game after some mindless hauling that shouldn't take more than a couple of hours.Those are the two core aspects of the game, and both feels shallow - which is weird, because the presentation of the game is amazing. However, all the systems are in place, and both Combat and Trading can be further expanded, balanced or fixed, because the design isn't FUBAR. So there IS hope for Cosmonautica.I did enjoy the research feature and how it's implemented - In my opinion, it's a pretty unique system. And the semi-realistic "orbital" flight is a fresh take on space flight in games.Assembling your crew is cool, and watching they develop is great. Building your rooms to tailor your ship to your playstyle feels great, too. Being able to change ship and uniform colors is also a nice touch.The comedy undertone and popular references are fun to have.So it REALLY boils down to the core gameplay - which was an unpleasant surprise after I got used to the whole interface, systems and setting.If you are looking for a very simple trading game that can be played only with the mouse, go ahead. But anything more than that, and I can't guarantee it'll meet your expectations at the moment. I really hope the devs expand and focus on the core gameplay before the actual release. Cosmonautica was on my wishlist for a long while, and just because I don't recommend it RIGHT NOW, doesn't mean I won't change my opinion later.With proper depth, more focus os the core gameplay and a bit more complexity, Cosmonautica can be one of the gems of Steam. Otherwise, it'll definitely fall short, with the only positive point being that "it only costs 15 USD"..so my final advice is: wait before buying.Thanks for reading!

												Cosmonautica is... almost the game i've been looking for for many years.  It's very significant that although at this stage, the game does crash about once an hour, I don't seem to mind (and this usually causes me to rant).Cosmonautica is a cute, humourous game where you manage your (at the start, very shoddy) spaceship and crew. There's trading, smugglin, passenger transportation and fighting. You can upgrade your ship's rooms by installing a science module and hiring a scientist.The trading takes a while to get used to, but after a bit of practice it's possible to make a profit margin. However, this wll not be sufficient to amass a fortune: i find that at the start it's best to concentrate on a combination of trading and passenger transportation to make a living. Fighting is best left to a little later, as your starting ship and crew aren't worth much in a fight yet :)All in all, a very very nice game, with the potential to be a great game if the developpers keep adding features, missions and new upgrades for your ship. (Maybe even ground 'away' missions?)PROS:- Nice cartoony graphics- Funny, without ever becoming obnoxious- Good balance between trading/fighting/transportation...- Some learning curve at the start but not too hard after a few hours' practice- Very addictive as you want to keep improving your ship, crew and fortuneCONS:- Occasional 'freeze' crashes (the game litterally just left early access so I imagine they will fix this soon)- The fights do feel a bit 'light'WISHLIST:I feel the game could be really great but just needs to be 'fleshed out' some. So for what it's worth, here's my wishlist :)- FIx the 'freeze' crash issues- Make some more variation for the crew (both graphical and in personality complexity, backstory etc...)- Flesh the fights out some more: these feel a bit 'light', no real sense of danger or damage (some sound changes and a slight speed up of pace perhaps?)- More and more diverse missions available on space stations - possibly even longer missions requiring more steps- 'Away' missions on planetary surfaces.Anyway, I heartily recommend this game to lovers of Sid Meier's Pirates, the Hitch Hiker's Guide or Firefly! FIND A CREW - FIND A JOB - KEEP FLYING  ;)

												Have played a fair amount of this pre-release and post-release. There are lots of positives here but not enough currently to keep my interest. Here are a few headlines if you're on the fence: PRO'S Decent crossover of SIMS/Space Trader. A reasonable amount of ships to save up for. Lots of star systems to explore, though this isn't really encouraged as much as it could be in the story mode. Graphics are cartoony and bright. Missions are fairly varied. CON'SLots of crashes - even after 'finished' release. As mentioned in other reviews - economy is fairly static and doesn't always make sense. A planet that exports robots only has 10 tons at any given time? How is that an export system? Lots of bugs - trade bugs will regularly put you into a negative balance. Mission text doesn't always reflect mission outcomes, Combat - DULL, DULL, DULL. No speed up option, most fights end up in either a stalemate or are a simple matter of 'Charge all guns blazing'. SIMS element is underplayed - characters don't really interact enough. Trading is incredibly tedious - see above on static economy. So I bought a ship with 80 units of space but the market only has 4 units of what I need? And it only regenerates at 2 units per 2 days? EXCELLENT. Autosave feature means that if something goes badly wrong (see negative cash balance bugs) then you are completely scuppered. Some grammatical errors and generally unpolished text entries. It's a shame - the game tries to shine in two genres but doesn't really take off in either. Hopefully this game will get more patches and content as it goes along - for now I would only pick this up if you want to grab it while its on sale and you don't mind learning the ropes of an unfinished game that has a lot of potential. - DG.

Early Access Review
								The game scratched my itch for an trading and exploration game, but i feel like i reached the bottom to soon.I enjoyed the 9h of gameplay i got out of it so far. The graphics and animation quality is very impressive, and I like the design work very much. Buying resources, travelling and reselling them for a profit feels good. Ontop of that, there are missions on every planet, e.g. to transport people to a certain planet. However, the variety among these missions is extremely limited. It feels like they are always the same ~10 missions, no matter which planet. I also do not quite understand the point of the additional solar systems one can travel to. They have certain shifts in the distribution of resources you can buy and sell, but offer nothing new at all otherwise. The quests are the same, the goods are essentially the same as well. Also, I got through my games - so far - without requiring any weapons what so ever. I think forcing the player to aquire some weapons as defense would be a good idea, i.e. by throwing the player into combat every now and then. This happened for me once, but i could easily flee without any repercussions. This is a shame, because forcing more combat on the player could be a way of disturbing them from the much more efficient strategy of peacefully buying and reselling expensive goods.There are still a good number of bugs, too. From missing planet names in the main scenario mission descriptions to a straight up crash (happened once, and was mitigated by the apparently very regular autosaving). I only had 2 different ships, I never did any hacking, I avoided combat without any problem. And still, I do not feel too much incentive in going those routes either, because I don't expect to find anything new. Sid Meier's Pirates created depth through Diplomatic relationships, progression of the main character (becoming the best pirate, avenging your family), and showed variety through a number of minigames. Both variety and depth are unfortunately lacking in Cosmonautica.In total, I do not regret having spent 10Euros for an enjoyable 9h of gameplay. And maybe, if some variety is added until release or after, I might revisit it for another 10h. So I would still recommend to anyone who likes space adventure and economic games.

Early Access Review
								Cosmonautica for a early release game is suprisingly fairly well poilished.  You will embark as a fledgling trader and slowly build up wealth allowing you to upgrade your ship and hire on new crew;than buy a better ship only to better upgrade it and hire on more crew; all the while attempting to find the best trade routes to make more money. Pros:-  Graphics are well done, having a cartoony look/atmosphere to them.  While at first I was kind of taken back by it but quickly loved it especially as you start finding all the underlaying humor and quips at famous movies, punch lines, and even the dev's add in their own humor with the writing in game.  - The witty humor and comical movie referances really add a refreashing change to present games.  I personally enjoy actually reading the mission briefings and alerts because there is always a light hearted feel to it.  I've found this has actually made me enjoy the "montonity" of doing trade runs, transporting passangers, smuggeling goods because there is always some underlaying humor written.-  The music is enjoyable and envelopes you into the atmosphire of the game.-  When you load the game, there is a ticker on the bottom of the screen that the devs update including a ETA as when to the next patch/update can be expected.  This I EXTREAMLY love because this lets you know that this game is being continously worked on and re-enforces that the investment you put into the game is actually valued.-  The tech tree is enjoyable and adds a nice twist to the game.-  You are able to customize your ship from the inside,(and external coloring as well as ship name) allowing you to have a real visual of what the ship looks like inside.        - On the topic of being to see inside of your ship, you are able to actaully see your crew go about doing their duties and performing defferent actions.  Nice touch.-  Crew members will gain exp allowing you to invest points to improve their current specialty, or you can try unlocking two other possiable skills they posses.  They also may have secondary skills, either being good or negative.  Plus crew histories are a wee bit comical to read as well.- You are not limited to just one solor system, there are others out there, how ever, you need to research them first before unlocking them.Now before we continue onto the cons, just remember this is a early access game and it does seem the devs really do care and are striving to produce the best game they can produce.Cons:- No campaign (yet).  Sadly there is only a tutorial mode or sandbox mode atm.  However there is a campaing button but it is greyed out but it states it's coming soon.  Really hope they release it soon but I'll keep playing the sandbox mode for how, still a lot to do.-  The time passing in game seems a bit quirky.  One game play movement was slow and it'd take me a few days in game to get from one planet to another, but later in another game play, it'd be crazy fast.  I really don't know if it was from upgrading to a newer ship and researching the engines to improve them (now that I think about it, that may be the case, but I digress)- NO SAVE FEATURE? Come on.  There "is" one, when you quit the game, but I'm not used to that.  I wish there was at least a choice in the options to either be a "realistic save" (save only upon quit) or "normal save" (allowing you to save when you want.  This being said, there were a few instances where the game had crashed and somehow the game saved before being close, resulting in me being spawned into a space port but the money I made selling goods was in my bank and upgrades to my ship were intact.-With no campaign so there is'nt any end-game content.  HOWEVER, it IS still very fun and I actually do enjoy playing this game so...keep that in mindAll in all, for $10, this game is well worth it's weight in salt.  I whole heartedly recommend this game.  Just keep in mind it's EARLY ACCESS, so be ready for a few bugs and issues.  Other than that, download and enjoy!

A lot of money. At the end of the day just focus on cargo and passengers and if a fight arises, just call the aggressor and pay a ransom, its much cheaper ($600-$2500) than all the above requirements.Crew members can go on strike if their needs are not met. What are their needs? Whos knows, clicking on the profile of a striker reveals no negative information, though occasionaly before strike you may see some negative effect which, more often than not, is getting a bee in their bonnet due to another crew mate having a different food preference. Seriously! The more they are levelled up the crazier they get.The tutorial is inadequate with the trading section been the end of it and from memory finishes with "you have 14 days to do some trading". Thats not a tutorial, and by the time you get up to some combat, your paying for a lot of trial and error.The game crashes quite reguarly, once or twice every hour with a runtime error, thats apparently wide spread.Jobs given out from spacestations quite often require sourcing and delivery of 30x of X resource, however there is very rarely enough of that resource in the whole system to suffice the job.Sometimes smuggling jobs start from A and involve collecting contraband from planets B and C to deliver to D. Note: This game has been given to me for free for review purposes.OverviewCosmonautica is a space economy simulator in which you take control of a small ship and sail through the galaxies, trading, transporting people, fighting baddies or by doing black market business, and earn money to customize, upgrade and manage your vessel, either by researching rooms and improvements or training your staff (or hiring better ones). Overall, this is a nice game which is what many players wanted to have from a game.The Pros:Humorous - This game has uplifting, groovy music, caricaturized characters, and funny dialogue options. It's clear that this is the kind of loose simulator that doesn't take it too seriously, but surprisingly enough, it is packed with features. I liked that it was able to offer so much versatility while still keeping it fun.The Art Style - One of the first things you notice is the brightly colored, cartoony graphics that the game uses. For some reason it just feels right for what this game is trying to achieve, considering the humorous nature of the game. The game runs very smoothly and has a decent set of graphical options and resolutions.Freedoooom! - The game has two modes: Campaign and Sandbox. Other than that campaign mode has predetermined solar systems and a short questline, whereas sandbox randomises your start and contains no starting questline, they are identical in gameplay and neither restrict you. You are free to do as you please, which is to be expected from a simulation game.Randomised Versatility - There are many missions to undertake, goods to buy and sell, people to hire or fire and galaxies to explore, and the best thing is that this game randomises everything! Proceduraly generated Universe and random missions and crew-for-hire at all space stations.Excellent UI - The user interface is very well made. It manages to remain very organised and intuitive despite the fact that it displays a lot of info. The font is nice, the colors are well used, and it has a hint of Borderlands to it.Steam Integration - Apart from lacking co-op, this game has the basic Steam needs: Achievements, Trading Cards, and most importantly, Steam Cloud.The Cons:Grind Fest! - This game is very fun at first, but then it gets kind of repetitive, especially because everything must be researched!!! And this is an aspect that I really don't get. Ok, you need to research the outer rings of the solar systems in your computer to casually explore it, but why do I need to research an extended bedroom or bathroom or a kitchen, that I won't even install, but the people at the shipyard. It's like passing near Ikea but going to buy raw materials and reverse engineer a piece of furniture, then going to Ikea and have them sell it to you. What?! Also, these researches take time, a lot of time, and during that time you are bound to grind away, trading through space. I wish it was less grindy and a bit... realistic? Also, trading is what you will mostly end up doing throughout the game, so if you like this kind of activity, great! But if you are a more action oriented gamer, this game is not for you.Unsatisfactory Combat - No matter how skilled your crew is, they will somehow find a way to screw battles up. Some of them straight off go to sleep while others fire missiles at the enemy, and sometimes the Pilot will just move in random directions, even fleeing despite the fact that you would clearly win. The combat system needs more polish.You... Don't Exist! - You are a god-like being, almost controling your crew like the Sims, but you don't exist. You don't appear, nor have a room in the space ship. It's like you are telepathically making decisions, which is a little disappointing. I mean, it would have been great to have yourself as a no-fee employee and improve your skills and such over time. But the game and everything in it treats you like you do exist, such as NPCs and mission dialogues.Impossible Perfect Late Game - This game almost tries to tell you that you shouldn't aspire to be the best - because if you do upgrade your ship and your crew to great heights, you will be very sad to find out that your upkeep will be so high, that it's almost impossible to make ends meet.ConclusionSo, is this game worth it? Well, yes and no. I recommend this game to anyone who likes space exploration and trading, and enjoys micromanaging everything, even if you have to do the same things over and over again. People who like trading games will surely like this one. For people who want the complete space experience however, this isn't the game for you. It features lots of great elements from other great games and tries to cram them all in one, but something is still missing. The poorly made battle system and the long wait of pointless research make it enjoyable only for some.If you liked this review or want to see more of my recommended games, you can view all my OCG reviews here, and be sure to follow our curator group:  Original Curator Group

The tutorial is done well, giving you a purpose and trying to explain how to get further out and explore. But it doesn't hold your hand, you need to at least understand the basics of the "buy low and sell high" trading dynamic for the basic profits. Sandbox fits the description with no requirements but your own, and the campaign is not yet done.The gameplay is set very similar to the Sim Tower style of placing rooms inside a ship for the crew needs, then hiring your choice of crew for tasks. You can set the tasks and leisure times of the crew and need to balance it all to run effectively. Don't waste crew overlapping a task when you only need one piloting at a time or cramming the bunk beds cause you didn't realize everyone's off-duty at the same time. So it has some management and planning, but its not quite like the more modern Sims - you don't command the crew directly. Just have them do their tasks and slot the timing. Then watch. The main game is the trading and travel, with the extras on the side.Crew can level up and get better, but the higher levels also mean more needs and demands, and its up to you to supply that for the voyage. You can mitigate some of it by shore leave by staying at stations for a day before a trip, but they may get stressed out on longer trips if you don't have appropriate facilities on board. And that's back to the ship planning and room layout, much like the older Sim Tower as I said. If you ever played that game enough, you'll get this easy. Took me a bitto figure out the staying at a station part, but that was really helpful once I got it - just speed up the "time" while docked. You pay the crew for sitting still, but they get relaxed for it better than you usually can on a trip with the ship.Ship travel is selected by you, but the speed is all determined by the pilot skills, if you have a pilot for all 4 shifts, the ship goes faster. But not all skills like that need to be so extensive, and you'll find yourself shuffling the crew roster over time for the right mix of skills as it kind of becomes a test vs the RNG to get the right mix together. Each crewmember also has needs and specials, and you'll find yourself constantly rethinking which crew you have as you may end up with needs you don't want - and overeater can kill your plans for having the cook on board, and a sporty one that needs a fitness room you can't place well can be annoying. But that's back to the shore leave for a solution sometimes, and you'll make do.The primary game is mainly trading, buy low and sell high. You can also become an exclusive transport for passengers or piracy in it, but the game needs some balance between it all for it to work out better. Piracy doesn't pay nearly as well as trading, and passengers can work out but needs some tweaking for the delivery time and rewards to really pay off for the investment. And not all tasks can be done well. Certain crew mixed and ship designes just can't accommodate certain ammounts of passenggers, and the combat is something else...The space travel around the stars are split between 3 rings. The Inner set is the safe zone - no piracy, short trips and easy to get to locations. The Middle has a chance of piracy towards the outter edge, but not frequent. It has longer travels and really requires the ship to start running effectively. The Outer is the hardest. It can have some of the most lucrative trading options out there, but its the hardest to get through with the Piracy almost guarenteed. To gain acess to the rings you need to research it, another crew task, with another room requirement. It can also be used to research other stars to travel to for even more ring research for travel. There is other options for ship and room research, but not implemented as of this writing.Space combat is diferent than you'd expect. You command when the ship fires and activates its short-lived powers availible through certain rooms like hacking or shields. The movement is automatic tho, so its pretty fluid. Damage at this stage in Alpha doesn't mean its a doomed ship when your hull is 0, instead its more work for repair crews and strain for the trip. That and an opposing ship doesn't surrrender to a crippled ship, tho they will run when their health drops low. Perhaps some balance is needed to finish making the danger more real, without it becoming more troublesome. As it is, you need certain rooms that take up space for combat, and each swhip has certain limitations on how many weapon types it can use and where to place them.All and all, its a very promising game. Could use some polish and perhaps more tweaking here and there - but it does the concept well for how it wants to. Definetly one to watch for the future, especially with the intensive dev involvement here.

												OK so there's plenty of bad and good for this game. Let me lay my opinion on the line here from a couple of hours of initial gameplay (Which I have no doubt will grow to a few more [albeit modest] hours in the future)This is a casual game by far. In that sense I've personally found it rather zen. You've no doubt gotten a fair idea of what the gameplay is. You manage a crew in a basic sense aboard your vessel. You travel around, first, one solar system trading, smuggling and fighting to accrue money. This cash goes towards bigger vessels and more capability to extend your activities further abroad. Beyond that overall premise, you have to manage the crew you use to staff said craft and their relationships and needs. As they become more skilled they require more effort to keep them satisfied (A feature which, thanks to a recent addition of bonuses, you can come close to bypassing to an extent early on if the money is flowing),If you are someone like me that's happy to provide a narrative (Other Dwarf Fortress and Paradox Grand Strategy players will understand) for the game you'll enjoy this, but superficially. There's plenty of capacity to do so but it is provided with a quite limited depth.There's a comedic element to the game which works quite well, but I personally don't take that in too much as (as mentioned above) I enjoy supplying my own narrative to the game. That being said it provides a level of enjoyment to the game even if it can be found to reduce the 'immersion' factor.To give a TL;DR overview though, if you are looking for a relaxing game set around Captaining a ship and crew while jaunting around getting into whatever adventures you see fit, this is a great game to destress to. If you want more complexity in your zero-G adventuring, check out the X series or EVE online.All being said and done, with the above caveats, I will recommend this title as a simple, enjoyable and satisfying experience. Additionally, the devs seem to be taking comments on board and working to adjust gameplay in an ongoing fashion.PS. A couple of things that I think this game requires:- The ability to speed up time to a greater extent- More intricate and involved crew requirements and procedural command events (There are some, I hope there will be more as I go on)Overall, once again, I've found this a relaxing and satisfying game. It will likely get repetative in the future (And I will update my review accordingly) however that's the lot of a ship captain in reality isn't it? Haul cargo, wash rinse and repeat with a dash of combat and smuggling to make it interesting. If the devs continue to update accordingly, it will continue to satisfy unless you're looking for an ultra-deep and complex experience. In that case, look elsewhere.

												It's billed as a 'Space Trading Adventure', but this buggy game is a poor port of a poor mobile game, with very little adventure and very little trading.On the surface, it seems interesting. You have to keep your interstellar crew happy while they zip around the galaxy, fighting and trading. So it has a Sims aspect to it. But here, as in so many other areas, the execution is poor. So this is a bit of leveling up strategy, or someone to look for when hiring crew. But later in the game, you can get robots to do the menial work, removing the need to bother with it. Strategy removed.As for the trading, it doesn't make sense. Some planets consume, some produce. But there is no overview of this. What's more, it's not very lucrative, compared to...Combat. Here is where the game is completely broken. Combat involves 'tapping' buttons at the right time. There's not much to it. But compared to trading, it's insanely profitable. There really is no reason to trade. Once you have their hull down to 15%, they will be on the phone to you, offering 40k, 50k, 60k to let them live. Compared to the 7k you can make hauling cigarettes across the map and back. And once you've figured this out, in a matter of hours you'll have the most expensive ship in the game. And then, there is no game anymore.Yes, there's a story, whatever.Finally, it crashes. A lot. There are in game bugs as well.Stay away.

												I love the idea of this game, but the implementation leaves a lot to be desired. I can not recommend this game.Cosmonautica does a lot of things right, unfortunately it does several critical things wrong.  The humor, the graphics, the sound, the visuals are all spot on and to be admired. It's a fun game to get into. But once you do, and get a little bit into the game, the flaws begin to show through and severely limit your ability to play.The biggest flaw I came across was a severe lack of balance and difficulty. This is a simple change that could be fixed with the addition of a difficulty slider. See, when you have a game where you trade for credits, that economic model needs to be spot on. Unfortunately even if you do everything 100% correct, the profit margins on trading are razor thin.In two hours of play, making only positive trades, I barely was able to re-attain the amount of capital (20k credits) I started the game with as seed money. Another hour and a half later and I was still only around the 30k. Now on it's own, this might be acceptable for some. A game where you have to micromanage razor thin profit margins and grind out credits might be acceptable. But this was all while I was making perfect trades and always turning profit. If you take a loss, at any time, it's absolutely devastating. After 3.5 hours play I got stopped by a cop and had a 15% chance of getting caught. RNG came up and I got caught. This caused me to fail my current quest, which penalized me credits, lost all my cargo, and was banned from that world for 15 days. The effects of this were absolutely devastating to my game, knocking me down well below the 20k mark just to get to a new planet, refitted, and get a new hold of cargo. IE one random chance event, that could only happen 3 out of 20 times, and I'd lost around two hours of gameplay.The further issue in the game is in the absolutely horrible combat system. You run out of ammo FAR too quickly, far more quickly than you can possibly take out even the weakest of pirates.  Forget about harder difficulty ships, you don't stand a chance. Ramming doesn’t even work, because the AI can avoid you forever.I think Cosmonautica has the potential for a good game, but it feels like an unfinished beta at this point.  I would HIGHLY recommend against buying this game at the current state it's in.  (v1.2)

Posted: April 17, 2016
												SimTower meets PrivateerInteresting combination of game elements in a manner that shouldn't work, but somehow does.  Interesting range of ships (but needs to be bigger and include more classes), the commodity model is reasonable (albeit rather basic), very similar to the Privateer model of base types, except that this game allows for bases to be multiple 'types'.Crew recruitment and requirements can be counter-intuitive and frustrating, especially with limited options at each base and the need to build up a large crew over time.  I would have thought that having a crew that eats different things would lead to better harmony as they're not all competing for the same subset of the food supply (but that's me I guess).Upskilling crew has one SERIOUS limitation; you don't get to choose the additional skill you would like a crew member to learn if you want to multi-skill them.  This to me is a massive flaw and not representative of the real world, where bosses have a large say in what development paths you follow.  Additionally, the random assignment of special attributes is great during upskilling except that it introduces negative traits quite a bit.  I understand that as people become more specialised they can become less adept in other areas, but given that it's an upskill, at least have special attributes balanced; +1 something, -1 something else.Combat (before you're ready for it) is even more frustrating because the flee move doesn't seem to actually allow you to evade combat; it should if the game is to be properly balanced IMHO)Mission choices are extremely limited (like Privateer) but the class of missions seems to be even smaller.  Combat, smuggling, or delivery (cargo or passengers).  That would be fine if there was a larger range of destinations and missions to choose from, but there isn't.Finally, I think the biggest concern I have is that the Devs seem to have moved on to new projects, announcing there is no longer full time support going into this game.  Don't get me wrong; I like the game, but it's incomplete.  There are still some crashes that occur semi-regularly in the game, and there needs to be more content developed for the game to increase choice and range.  I'd like to see more effort put into getting this game right before new games receive focus.Pros:  Reasonably simple trading model, nice touch of ship management with crew, so long as it doesn't impact the flow of the game.Cons: Frustrating crew recruitment and upskilling, poor range of choice generally (ships, missions, new crew, pretty much everything), and no more full time support from the devs.While I recommend this game, I'd love a button for 'undecided'.  It's about a 55/45 split for me at the moment, although I intend to put more time into it to see if familiarity and learning curve change the balance somewhat.  Original fusion of ideas, but needs more polish.

Manage your ship or the ship will manage you out of a job and into a game over. Take risks with missions in transporting goods that aren't quite listed on the legal side of the law. Don't get caught or you'll pay a hefty fine. Hopefully you have the money to bribe or pay the fine. If not, good luck building it back up again.You can add "modules" to the interior of your ship so that it is fitted with the right amount of crew space, cargo holds and necessities to control your space place. Change the name of your ship and the varying color scheme. Change the crews uniform color as well while you are at it.Overall I'm very happy I made this purchase and have supported what seems to be a very well rounded group of indie developers who are doing their best to deliver what was promised. I hope somebody finds this information useful.***UPDATE****After a few updates the game was running much better. Crashes were less often, almost non-existent for me.The problems I began to notice over a longer period of time playing related to the buying and selling of goods from planet/station to planet/station. It was very rare in the first solar system phase that I was able to make a profit on selling goods I purchased at locations that needed that maeterial. This was the biggest disappointment for me. The Contracts were interesting and had some thought put into them. However, managing the location you were headed, how long it would take to get there, how much money you have and whether you can afford to pay your staff, as well as what time limits you have on the contracts you currently have makes it very difficult to plan out a path to make the Contracts truly valuable.I've never had a very successful time during space battles. I haven't played a single save to the point where I am able to get more highly skilled shipmates to see if that makes the space battles less of a chore. Battles don't occur frequently however.Overall this game is interesting but I want to see more contracts made available per station, some login put into the contracts time required to complete, ways to truly build up a profit by buying goods at low cost and selling them at a high payout dependant on needs per location.What I want is a game where I can build my own spaceship, manage my crew, modify the functions of my space ship as to whether it's a space ferry, cargo ship, mercenary, or smuggler. This game has that potential but needs more fine tuning.

												I let the Mixed reviews keep me from buying the game sooner and I wish I hadn't. If you're looking for a game like Freelancer, or Sid Meier's Priates!, you'll find that Cosmonautica scratches that hard to reach itch. The difficulty games is that this is a very specific, niche genre.  A lot of games aim for it but few games hit the mark. Like Cosmonautica, many games let you choose what kind of space captain you'll be: trader, pirate, smuggler, etc. But many of those games (Eve Online or the X series) are too tecnhical as spaceflight simulations and the UI and learning curve is too steep to be fun. They lack the simple fun that more arcadey controls and mechanics give you.  Other games like Rebel Galaxy or Windward are arcadey enough, but they lack depth and immerseive world-building--the sandbox is too shallow and uninteresting. Other games take the economics too far and require either spreadsheet level optimization, or a wiki research project before you fully understand the mechanics (Patrician series, Europa, etc.). Or they keep the economics straightfoward like Tropico but they focus on city- or empire-management (like Civ or Stellaris). They don't have the Firefly sense of adventure that comes from a ship-centric game like Pirates! or Freelancer. Lastly some games make you feel alone in space and lack the human-element: there's no Sims style management of crew needs. No Space Colony style workforce management. Without any RPG-style progression via crew experience or ship upgrades, some games are just a grind without cool mid- and end-game mechanics.Cosmonautica balances all these things pretty well. The art-style is warm like a Blizzard game. The economy and world-building is complex enough to be stimulating but straightforward enough not to require spreadsheets or wiki research. The gameplay centers on the ship's adventure through space rather than being city-and empire-centered. The world is populated with life, a human crew that needs your care and feeding. The ship upgrade system isn't a linear grind of getting the same thing with better numbers; it's specializing your ship for trading, combat, smuggling, hacking, etc. and choosing the best gear to fill your limited space with (ship upgrades use a similar system as Fallout Shelter, or whatever the vault-builder thing is called).It has its flaws. Sometimes a mission or something is game-breakingly good and feels like a cheat because it rewards you much better than anything else. Or the reverse, you may take a mission that is simply unprofitable upon success and feels like a bug for punishing you. Story mode has an instructive mainline quest that plays like a tutorial which is nice. But your inital ship and resources are so lousy that it takes longer than it should to establish yourself and unlock the more interesting gameplay. So you are forced to plow through a more prolonged 'rat-killing' phase before things get richer. Bottom line, it falls short of Pirates! or Freelancer because those games were polished, big-budget classics and Cosmonautica is an indie game with some rough edges. It scratches your itch but it doesn't quite let you relive your nostaliga for those games.

												TL;DR: Nice, casual space trading game, not for people seeking challenge or complex economy sims.This is a nice, relaxing casual game which is worth the price if what you are looking for is a moderately entertaining game where you click things and numbers go higher.While it is not as shallow as an actual clicker game, after a few hours of having fun with the game you slowly realize that there isn't really that much that can go wrong, which makes the already dull combat system feel pointless (you can also usually skip combat simply by communicating with your enemy and he will let you go, sometimes for free, sometimes for like 300 credits, which is basically nothing).Your crew never really has any real complaints (and you can completely ignore their needs for a loong time without consequence anyway) and you can easily replace anyone.Random events make no impact as they come unexpectedly but are explained in such a weird way that the player will often not understand what the result means in gameplay terms.The character traits of your crewmates really seems completely cosmetic, you dont see any interaction between NPC's like them talking or doing anything social aboard the ship (I guess autism is a big thing in the future)Trading is ok, since its very relaxing, but there is not enough economy simulation to really make it interesting (You can mostly sell the same things at the same prices and the same places, limited only by the amount of the commodity a planet can store)The graphics are pretty much sufficient for this kind of game, it has a friendly cartoonish look with a few nice details to make it feel more alive but i can imagine people not liking the style.All in all, I would recommend this game to people who are looking for something to pass time without needing much commitment or quick reaction time. If you enjoy casual trading and space exploration games and aren't interested in the mechanics behind what is happening in a game you will probably spend 10 enjoyable hours with this title.

Fun but flawedCosmonautica deserves to be recommended, but only in a Steam sale, and here's why.I picked Cosmonautica up after discovering Space Colony, but whilst both offer essentially the same prospect of The Sims meets an RTS in space, they are very different beasts. For those not familiar with Space Colony (in which case you're missing a treat) it's a micro-management city builder with some fairly basic but well-developed Sims dropped in - give them what the need and they'll mostly look after themselves, but you still need to intervene to keep them friendly (and more) towards each other, and occassionally to restore their sanity. The first couple of missions are a bit clunky as the game wants you to know that this is important stuff, but later on you're so pushed for time building your base, and managing resources, plant life and alien incursions, that keeping a happy crew becomes both a challenging and enjoyable element of the game. And as well as the two-pronged (civil / military) split campaign you get a good variety of challenge maps and an editor in the package.Unfortunately this may have set my bar rather high.Cosmonautica is more like the Sims meets Pirates!, but it doesn't quite hit the mark, and now I've played enough of it I'm realising why, and it's fundamental flaw is in pandering too much to casual gaming. The (single) campaign starts out promisingly enough but it falls down in a few key areas. The crew management is essentially limited to picking the right team (tip: make sure they all eat the same food and don't promote them beyond level 2 until they can at least sleep, eat, wash, exercise, play games and take pills and they'll never fall out or complain about anything). The biogs are nice but very short, which wouldn't matter were it not for the fact that the game offers hardly any opportunities for them to stand out individually.   The ship battles are also disappointing, and even more so because it wouldn't take much to fix them. Here Cosmonautica really wants to be Pirates!, but the touch-friendly interface (with no keyboard controls) limits manouvering to basic commands (circle left / right, etc) and Pirates! fans will be bashing their cursor pads in frustration. Without better controls battles basically amount to working out whether to fight or flee, and then slowly getting close enough to begin playing whack-a-mole with command icons until the other ship gives up or blows up. Battles just aren't fun, and all it needed to do was copy Pirates!   And finally there's the downtime when travelling between planets. Even if there was much to the crew management, travelling in normal time would bore you to death, and travelling in fast time doesn't give you a big enough gap to think through and make any decisions. So trips are reduced to the sort of 20-30 second turn times you'd complain about on a turn-based strategy.  In short, Cosmonautica is a missed opportunity. I've not completed it yet so have no idea how far in I am, but I've got myself a nice cruiser and unlocked all the science upgrades except for whatever's left of the galaxy hexes, and I'm going to finish the campaign and probably grind my way to buying a top tier ship, but with only a sandbox as an alternative to the campaign I'm not sure I'll be coming back afterwards.It's still very polished, and as one of the more involving casual games it's fun, but put it up against even an old RTS or trader and you'll soon see its flaws.

The pay is implied as being given in exchange for not boarding or attacking your ship, so why or how would they know those goods are there?  This game is infuriating, half because I like it so much and half because it isn't fun to play when there is no reason to take the big risks specifically because you will ALWAYS get caught. Not being able to adjust the window size is also a minor annoyance, having it allways about 5 pixels wider than my screen.Also you can sometimes manage the flightpath issue by selecting other destinations when it goes wrong (usually a huge loop out in front of the planets orbit when half way there) to force a course-change, then change back again. It requires some micro-management.Ship and tech progression don't match well and it's very easy to run on with the storyline then realise you've progressed yourself into an unwinable situation. Ship combat also isn't well explained. It does feel like it's missing its final polish.The way you manage your crew however is very nice and creative with the morale system, and when you do upgrade your ship it is fun kitting it out. Building up a ship is rewarding, especially once you start stacking multiple jobs for destinations.So despite its flaws, it's still a fun game. Get it while it's cheap.

Still rough around the edges, but oh so much potential!If the devs for EVE Online stayed up hacking for 3 straight days, wired on Jolt and watching Futurama, Cosmonautica might have been the result. Definitely not for everyone; while it does have a very primitive combat interface it’s essentially a resource management sim.  I love simulation type "games" and mini/max micro management, so I was completely addicted immediately.  It actually reminds me somewhat of Galactic Civ.I also like that it is a very focused, solid game. It is an un-abashed, un-apologetic space trading and resource management sim. i.e. a very targeted, niche type game and it doesn't tack on random elements from other types of games trying to appeal to a wider market...all without taking itself too seriously.That said, be warned that its very obvious that Comonautica is still on it initial shake-down cruise, however the autosave is so transparent and well implemented that I've never lost more than 2 or 3 minutes of play.  PROS  Very polished, if quirky, artwork.  Each crew member is an indevidual with personal traits.  Various "missions" in addition to pure trading.  Multiple planetary system types and industries.  Very unique, "orbital" movement system.  Interesting tech system.  Large number of inter-dependant industries and resources.  Adult, Geek themed humor.  Solid, focused "game" play.  Massive potential for greatness.CONS  The "campaign" is woefully short and has exactly zero re-play potential.  It's a management sim. If you want a space shooter/world builder you'll hate it.  Version 1.x, it will crash. Have faith that it will improve.  Version 1.x, limited content, no DLC (yet?)  Version 1.x, nearly zero documentation.  Some parts of the interface are awkward and/or non-intuitive.-V

So, if you want to be successful in Cosmonautica, it's just very very simple: use torpedoes (in combats) and trade high-priced commodities (in trading). Early Access Review
								Nope.  Unless you enjoy FTL type games where 90% of the gameplay is luck based, you'll just end up frustrated.  I've played 4 games in a row, every single one ending in failure due to some form of bad luck and lack of information.  For example, the last one.  Trying to get some early game money, still trying to fill spots on my crew with very limited cash.  I take a 1 skull mission to kill a pirate.  Right before the fight, one of the many ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ random events makes my repairman destroy one of my rooms then leaves them sick with a hangover.  Fight starts and I can't repair anything.  I also find out that my newly installed turret can't even scratch the enemy.  I retreat from the fight, and get docked $1500 for a failed mission.  Take the loss, try to recover.  Get a speeding ticket for $2500.  Try to recover again?  Don't have enough money left to invest in trade to make profit.  Try to sell pieces of ship to start over?  Does matter, crew is tantrum spiraling.  Money goes into negative, impossible to recover.The game is all about having enough money to make money.  But you quickly find out you can't reliably make money in the beginning, as the only forms of trade that can actually make profit (Such as computers) don't restock/empty fast enough to be continually used (at least in the Tutorial campaign).  This forces you into relying on missions for reliable income, which aren't as reliable as you'd think. Almost all item shipping missions seem to be smuggling with 50+/-% failure rates (you actually lose money and waste time each time you fail).  Having a hacker in your crew might help offset this, but I never got the chance to test it due to expenses.  NPC transport missions require you to take up extra room on your already tiny ship with passenger seats, which with the already lack of money and space, may be difficult to aquire/fit.  Pirate killing missions require a good weapons/shield setup (as above mentioned), which is expensive early game and again, takes up lots of ship room.Etc etc, long story short, TL;DR:  My experience was extremely frustrating and I would never recommend this, or any other Luck based game, to anyone.  Any strategy/simulation/eyecandy/humor the game has, feels masked by the potential of bad luck being able to just end your game at any time, wasting hours of grinding.  Not my cup of tea.

												Well, it's charming and fun to play, but unfortunately the gameplay still has some kinks in it. This game still needs some love and polish, and iterative playtesting, but since I'm actually enjoying myself playing it I have to recommend it.The good: it's fun to recruit a crew, train them up to be an efficient fighting machine, and travel the cosmos in search of fun and profit. This game gets those basics right. And the presentation is absolutely charming. And the solar systems use simple orbital mechanics! As a Kerbal Space Program player that's pretty damn awesome to see.There are some problems that stop the game short of true greatness. Aside from the storyline missions, the gameplay is rather repetitive. When you've seen one system, you've seen them all, especially if you're a combat vessel rather than a trader. There are only a handful of basic missions, and you see the same ones over and over again.There are also some balance/tuning issues that need to be addressed. For one thing, fighting other vessels produces OUTRAGEOUS profit, far beyond anything else. This is because when you're beating the enemy they hail you to surrender and offer money and cargo to let them live. That money is always much, much higher than any possible mission reward you were getting to fight them. A simple bounty mission might be around 7,500 credits, while the ransom is likely to be 42,000!Trading still doesn't produce much profit unless you go for the higher value goods. That's fine, except that when you sell goods to a station they remain in that station and slowly disappear over time (as the inhabitants use them up, presumably). The problem is that this decay rate is far too slow. You end up stuffing the planet full of goods and unable to sell because everyone is still working their way through the last batch. Basically, you have to sell to planets other than ones that actually have a demand for your goods, and I'm reasonably sure that you could glut a whole system without much trouble.Some of the crew roles simply aren't useful, ditto ship rooms. There's a galley that requires a cook to operate, but the starting food vending machine is more than adequate for a full crew, and by the time you've researched the tech for the galley it's a simple matter to research the upgrade that makes the galley operate without a cook. Since upgrades are done by researching a technology, and that technology is used by different unlocks or upgrades, it's quite easy to inadvertently unlock automating the galley because you unlocked the prereq techs for other benefits they unlock.Same story with medics/medbay - the pill dispenser works just as well, doesn't require training, and the medbay gets automated by upgrades.Crew preferences and interactions is a nice idea in theory but it's simple enough to get crewmates who all like the same food and then you never have to worry about it again.There isn't enough different mission text, so missions will repeat constantly. It's a very minor quibble, but it gets annoying reading the same description over and over and over.Basically, the game isn't balanced. The result is there's no real incentive to do anything other than what is most effective (ie, fight ships for outrageous ransoms). In a way you're punished for taking alternate approaches because they're so dismally ineffective by comparison.It feels like this game has tremendous potential that could be unlocked by gameplay tuning. This would turn it from a "pretty good" game to an amazingly fantastic one. That said, it's still a pretty good game, and you should get it.-----------------------------OLD, EARLY ACCESS REVIEW:Charming presentation and shows great promise, but needs more work on gameplay tuning before it's actually fun to play. Cargo trading, for example, produces barely any profit.This has every sign of becoming an excellent game, but it's not there yet, so I can't really recommend it (unless you just want to support them). The issues are easy enough to fix by simple iterative playtesting and balancing, so I don't expect this will stay a problem in the future.

												I almost quit this game a couple times, but kept coming back!  I've not played a game quite like this, and really hope they make a sequel.It's a mixture of The Sims (managing your space crew of pilots, shooters, scientists, hackers, cleaners, repairers, cooks, sorta like Fallout Shelter), spaceship customization (semi-grid based with tons of different options), space exploration, researching, trading, and cooldown based space combat (with shooting, shields, hacking, and maneuvers).  I liked the art style, the music, and especially customizing my ship.  It just needs a bit more polish and they will have a fantastic sequel!  Luckily their sequel should be much easier to polish, it turns out the engine (and dependencies) they locked themselves into had a lot of limitations that they couldn't escape in the end (I saw their post about it).  That makes me even more keen-eyed for a sequel!Polish you say?  These are some of the things I mean about polish.  They're not game-breaking in and of themselves, but for many people, this would have possibly been a death by a thousand cuts.  I kept with it because I hadn't played a game before that has quite this mixture of elements, and I really hope they make a sequel, so I am listing these things in hopes of seeing it for "Cosmonautica 2":1) Those gosh darn repairing and cleaning robots are so insanely loud and annoying (especially in speed-up mode) when you are trying to look at your ship (so loud and annoying that I don't really look at my ship that much when they are cleaning and repairing).  This wouldn't be so bad, but when assembling a team, you pretty much have to have them while you are searching for a crew that compliments your ships.2) We should be able to more easily customize our crew's talents.  Currently, when you level up a crew, you can either increase their current abilities OR choose to add a new ability.  VERY frustatingly, the new ability is RANDOM.  This makes it extremely tedious to find a good combination of people.  For instance, I would never want a hacker/shooter, nor a repairer/cleaning, nor a pilot/cleaner, the list goes on.  There are so many bad combinations.  This forces the player to hire a level 1 character until level 2, add the new ability, hope it's the right one, and then immediately fire them until they get the right combo.  2) Mods:  there could be so many cool new rooms, crews, ships, weapons, systems, materials, and whatnot for people to easily make and plop into the game.4) Trading and other items become tedious (there should be upgrades that improve the management flow as you go along), because there’s not any built-in way to catalog a list of materials that are created and/or needed in various systems.  You can’t even look at a different solar system without taking two days to travel there.  There should be a fun system of tracking and logging or something, so that way we don’t have to go and click on each planet, over, and over, and over.  Maybe a key that shows an overlay on the solar system if you have a certain skill, or have researched.  There just seems to be a lot of menu clicking and searching that could be done in a more central location (like on the entire solar system).  Another example would be trying to find out the condition of your ship (cleaness and repairedness) you have to click in every single room to get an idea, over-compensate with cleaning/repair, or just waste time and money repairing and cleaning by being tethered to shipyards (because that's the only other way to do it).  There should just be an option for an overlay.  Lots of simulation games use them, and I think it'd be a great addition.  Socialization is another tedious item, where you have to select the room, select the two people, and hit social and babysit it, or else they'll go on strike (you really have to wait until they've socialized enough over a long time sped up, which is silly, and then tell them manually to stop, this should be an automatic thing, and there should be other ways to fix this, like they should quit as soon as they've hit max relationship, which would make sense).  It just seems like a clunky system where almost no other need is manually or tedious (it needs at least SOME automation, again, like stopping when max AND a notification, the system for notifications is there, after all).5) Better save system, which would also have lessened the problems with crashing.  Other people have mentioned it, but you really have to restart the game every 45mins to an hour if you don’t want to crash.  It does save your game at every station stop (which is pretty often) BUT it is sad that it happens so much.  It should let you load one of the last 5 or so autosaves, autosave after battles, and allow for quick saves and manual saves.  This allows for experiementation and confidence in the system.  I'm not saying that this would make crashing okay, but if it had a better save system, I think it wouldn't have had as much backlash.  For instance, you could finish an awesome fight, grab loot/money and then crash on the way back and have to repeat the (sometimes tedious) battle all over again.6) Combat is very tedious at the beginning and didn't get semi-interesting until I had two shields, two hackers, 3 shooters, and a bigger ship.  Before this, you had to hit a couple gun buttons over, and over, and over, and over with the mouse waiting for cooldowns.  It's still not that interesting with all those things, but it's definitely good enough as just another aspect of the game, though.  However, it was tedious enough that I avoided it for the longest time.  One of the most annoying aspects of this is that there are no hotkeys for combat.  You have upwards of 8-10 different buttons to press all with the mouse bouncing around the screen (instead of being able to hotkey some or all of them).7) Better portraits:  yes, they start to look the same after a while, but I'm mostly talking about how these huge portraits at the bottom of the screen are fuzzy with no anti-aliasing (badly upscaled smaller portraits).8) Some little mechanical things still aren't clear, for instance, should I put a good shooter on my torpedo since it's so powerful and expensive?  It says that it's guided, but it also misses sometimes.  Why is one of my crew sleeping in a bunk, but the portrait says "taking a dump" and it seems to be confused about what it needs to do first?  Another example, I didn't know I could attempt to flee combat until waaay into the game.9)  There should be an option to tell characters to quickly go satisfy a need (and temporarily ignore their given tasks) if they're really in need, because they don't seem to use their time well.  I have everything fully upgraded, I don't have very high level characters, and I only give them 2/4 assignment slots per day, yet they still can't find enough time to feed, bathroom, and whatnot.10) More tutorial-like elements better spaced.  It would be nice if all elements were introduced in a safe environment in the first system (combat, smuggling, trading, scanning, person transport, socializing, etc), even if that means that you have to makeup some crazy reason that you get a temporarily powerful ship.  There's a lot of cool things in this game that don't show up (or you have no idea quite how they function) for a long time into the game.11) I'm not sure the leveling system is increasing XP logically all the time.  It only seems like crew get XP over time, and only when traveling.  This is weird, because then you shooters don't get any increased XP for fighing, hackers for hacking, etc.I may add some other things that come to mind, but keep in mind, I DO still recommend playing the game, because it’s a nifty idea that I hope they make a polished sequel for!!!  I am only listing these things because I think they should be some of the focuses on the next in the series.
